TestStep.Name: ID Spoofing 1 - ID Token (sub)
TestStep.Description:
ID Spoofing Attack

In this test we use the Attacker OP and create an ID Token containing the identity (sub) of the victim, which is controlled by another OP: Honest OP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an invalid ID Token containing the victim's identity in the sub claim.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the client accepts an ID Token AND logs the attacker into the victim's account.

Mitigation

The identity of an user is represented by the combination of the iss and sub claims. Therefore, both values MUST be used to authenticate the user.

TestStep.Name: ID Spoofing 2 - ID Token (sub+iss)
TestStep.Description:
ID Spoofing Attack

In this test we use the Attacker OP and create an ID Token containing the identity (iss+sub) of the victim, which is controlled by another OP: Honest OP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an invalid ID Token containing the victim's identity in the sub claim and the Honest OP as iss.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the client accepts an ID Token AND logs the attacker into the victim's account.

Mitigation

Step 2 in Section 3.1.3.7. OpenIDConnect-Core: The Issuer Identifier for the OpenID Provider (which is typically obtained during Discovery) MUST exactly match the value of the iss (issuer) Claim. within the ID Token.

TestStep.Name: ID Spoofing 3 - ID Token (name+username+email)
TestStep.Description:
ID Spoofing Attack

In this test we use the Attacker OP and create an ID client accepts an ID Token containing the identity (name+username+email) of the victim, which is controlled by another OP: Honest OP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues a valid ID Token containing victim's identity in the standard claims name, preferred_username, and email. The sub claim, which is part of the ID Token validation, is not spoofed and contains an identity controlled by the Attacker OP.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the client accepts the ID Token AND logs the attacker into the victim's account.

Mitigation

The identity of an user is represented by the combination of iss and sub. Thus, subclaims can be used only to retrieve further information regarding the user, but NOT for authentication. Currently, OpenID Connect does not provide any mechanisms to verify these statements.

TestStep.Name: ID Spoofing 4 - ID Token (sub, no iss)
TestStep.Description:
ID Spoofing Attack

In this test we use the Attacker OP to create an (invalid) ID Token containing the sub of the victim and no iss claim.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an invalid ID Token containing the victim's identity in the sub claim. The ID Token does not include an iss claim. If a UserInfo request is received, the victim's issuer identifier will be returned within the UserInfo response.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the client accepts the ID Token AND logs the attacker into the victim's account.

Mitigation

Step 2 in Section 3.1.3.7. OpenIDConnect-Core: The Issuer Identifier for the OpenID Provider (which is typically obtained during Discovery) MUST exactly match the value of the iss (issuer) Claim. within the ID Token.

Execution.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the client accepts an ID Token AND logs the attacker into the victim's account.

Mitigation

TestStep.Name: ID Spoofing 6 - UserInfo (sub+iss)
TestStep.Description:
ID Spoofing

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the sub parameter on the client by returning a maliciously crafted UserInfo response. The UserInfo response includes sub and iss claims of another OP - HonestOP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.and processes the UserInfo response.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token that contains a sub claim initialized with the identity of an entity controlled by the Evil OP. When the client requests UserInfo, a different sub value is returned along with UserInfo parameters belonging to a subject identifier registered with the Honest OP.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the attacker is logged into the victim's account (registered with Honest OP).

Mitigation

As per Section 5.3.2 of OpenID-Connect Core, The sub Claim in the UserInfo Response MUST be verified to exactly match the sub Claim in the ID Token; if they do not match, the UserInfo Response values MUST NOT be used.

TestStep.Name: ID Spoofing 7 - UserInfo (name+username+email)
TestStep.Description:
ID Spoofing

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the sub parameter on the client by returning a maliciously crafted UserInfo response.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow and processes the UserInfo response.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token, which contains sub initialized with the client_id of the client registered at the Evil OP. The provided UserInfo response does not include a sub claim but the claims name, preferred_username and email contain identifiers of the victim. Additionally, an iss claim is added that contains the issuer identifier of the victim's OP - Honest OP..

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the attacker is logged in the victim's account (registered with Honest OP) or if claims from the UserInfo response are processed.

Mitigation

As per Section 5.3.2 of OpenID-Connect Core, The sub Claim in the UserInfo Response MUST be verified to exactly match the sub Claim in the ID Token; if they do not match, the UserInfo Response values MUST NOT be used.

Prerequisites.

Execution.

TestStep.Name: ID Spoofing 12 - ID Token Header
TestStep.Description:
Sub Claim Spoofing (ID Token Header)

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the sub claim on the client by returning a maliciously crafted ID Token. RFC 7519, Section 5.3, allows to replicate the JWT claims iss, sub, aud within the JWT header with the intention of facilitating the processing of encrypted JWT bodys.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token with a malicious Header. The JWT header contains the victim's identity in a sub claim and the issuer identifier of the Honest OP in the iss claim. The unencrypted, signed body of the ID Token does not contain invalid data and should verify successfully.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the attacker is logged in the victim's account (registered with Honest OP).

Mitigation

A client receiving a JWT that includes header claims should not process claims from the unprotected header without proper verification: only the claims found in the protected (and succesfully verified) JWT payload are to be processed.

TestStep.Name: Issuer Confusion
TestStep.Description:
Issuer Confusion

In this test we use the Attacker OP to return maliciously crafted Discovery document (containing the issuer of the Honest OP) and afterwards to create an ID Token containing the identity (iss+sub) of the victim, which is controlled by another OP: Honest OP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

  • Step 1: PrOfESSOS returns an invalid issuer parameter during Discovery. The issuer is set to the value of the Honest OP.
  • Step 2: PrOfESSOS issues an invalid ID Token containing the victim's identity in the sub and the Honest OP as iss.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the client accepts the ID Token AND logs the attacker into the victim's account.

Mitigation

According to the description of the issuer value in Section 3. OpenIDConnect-Discovery: If Issuer discovery is supported (see Section 2), this value MUST be identical to the issuer value returned by WebFinger. This also MUST be identical to the iss Claim value in ID Tokens issued from this Issuer.

TestStep.Name: Key Confusion 1 - jwk Spoofing
TestStep.Description:
Key Confusion

In a Key Confusion attack, the attacker attempts to induce the client to use a key of the attacker's choice to validate the ID Token.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token containing valid signature signed with an untrusted key. The key is included in the ID Token as jwk member and referenced by the kid parameter.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the ID Token is accepted by the client.

Mitigation

As per OpenID Connect Core 1.0, Section 2, ID Tokens SHOULD NOT use the JWS or JWE x5u, x5c, jku, or jwk Header Parameter fields. Instead, references to keys used are communicated in advance using Discovery and Registration parameters.

TestStep.Name: Key Confusion 6 - Session Overwriting
TestStep.Description:
Key Confusion

In a Key Confusion attack, the attacker attempts to induce the client to use a key of the attacker's choice to validate the ID Token. This test applies a Session Overwriting attack in order to confuse the client to use the wrong key.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow. The client has the same client_id on the Honest and Malicious OP.

Execution.

  • Step 1: starts authentication with Malicious OP
  • Step 2: pause before sending the Authentication Response to the SP
  • Step 3: start authentication with Honest OP within the same HTTP session as Step 1 (i.e., use the same Cookies)
  • Step 4: abort Step 3 after the Honest IdP has been contacted by the Browser from Step 3.
  • Step 5: continue with Step 2 (break the pause) and sends the Authentication Response (code or idtoken/access token)

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the ID Token is accepted by the client.

Mitigation

The client must ensure to choose the correct verification key (client_secret) when validating the received ID Token. The validation key must correspond to the client_id AND the issuer contained in the ID Token.

TestStep.Name: Key Confusion 7.1 - MAC from PKCS1 RSA Key 1
TestStep.Description:
Key Confusion

In a Key Confusion attack, the attacker attempts to induce the client to use a key of the attacker's choice to validate the ID Token.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token containing a HS256 signature created using the PEM string of the PKCS1 encoded RSA public key as MAC key.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the ID Token is accepted by the client.

Mitigation

Clients must perform ID Token validation as defined OpenID Connect Core 10.0, Section 2 and Section 3.1.3.7. In particular, the specification states in Section 2, that ID Tokens SHOULD NOT use the JWS or JWE x5u, x5c, jku, or jwk Header Parameter fields. Instead, references to keys used are communicated in advance using Discovery and Registration parameters [...]. Furthermore, Section 3.1.3.7 requires that The alg value SHOULD be the default of RS256 or the algorithm sent by the Client in the id_token_signed_response_alg parameter during Registration.. With regards to MAC based ID Token signatures: If the JWT alg Header Parameter uses a MAC based algorithm such as HS256, HS384, or HS512, the octets of the UTF-8 representation of the client_secret corresponding to the client_id contained in the aud (audience) Claim are used as the key to validate the signature.

TestStep.Name: IdP Confusion
TestStep.Description:
IdP Confusion

In this test we use the Attacker OP to enforce the client to send a valid code issued by the Honest OP to the Attacker OP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the code flow. The attacker OP returns the same client_id during the registration as the one registered at the Honest OP. In other words, the client has same client_id on both OPs.

Execution.

  • Step 1: PrOfESSOS triggers an authentication on the client with the Honest OP. PrOfESSOS caches the received state and nonce parameters sent in the Authentication Request.
  • Step 2: PrOfESSOS starts an authentication on the client with the Malicious OP.
  • Step 3: PrOfESSOS receives the Authentication Request and responds with a HTTP 302 Redirect to the Honest OP. The redirect URL contains the same parameters as received in the Authentication Request except for the nonce parameter, which is replaced by the value from Step 1.
In case that the client does not use the nonce parameter, no parameter exchange in step 3 is needed.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the Malicious OP receives the code generated by the Honest OP in the Token Request.

Mitigation

The mitigation is currently discussed by the working groups.

TestStep.Name: Malicious Endpoint Attack
TestStep.Description:
Malicious Endpoint Attacks

In this test we use the Attacker OP to return a maliciously crafted Discovery document and afterwards to create an ID Token containing the identity of the victim, which is controlled by another OP Honest OP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

The Attacker OP returns the following configuration during the Discovery phase. 
{
	"issuer": "https://opivAttackerOP.com",
	"registration_endpoint": "https://opivHonestOP.com/register",
	"authorization_endpoint": "https://opivHonestOP.com/auth",
	"token_endpoint": "https://opivAttackerOP.com/token",
	"userinfo_endpoint": "https://opivAttackerOP.com/userinfo"
	...
}

Result Evaluation.

The goal of this test is to verify whether the End-User authentication can be broken. The attack is successful if the Attacker OP receives any secret information, for example, client_id, client_secret, code or access token, generated by the Honest OP. Injection and DoS attacks are considered out of scope for the tests provided by PrOfESSOS.

Mitigation

The mitigation of the attack is not officially specified yet, but currently discussed. The RFC drafts draft-ietf-oauth-mix-up-mitigation-01 and draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-12 discuss in detail how clients can ensure that they only process redirect responses of the OAuth authorization server they sent the respective request to and from the same user agent this authorization request was initiated with.

TestStep.Name: Session Overwriting 1
TestStep.Description:
Session Overwriting 1

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

The Session Overwriting test consists of five steps and requires the participation of the Attacker OP and the Honest OP.
  • Step 1: starts authentication with Honest OP
  • Step 2: pause before sending the Authentication Response (code or idtoken/access token) to the SP
  • Step 3: start authentication with Malicious OP within the same HTTP session as Step 1 (i.e., use the same Cookies)
  • Step 4: abort Step 3 after the Malicious IdP has been contacted by the Browser from Step 3.
  • Step 5: continue with Step 2 (break the pause) and sends the Authentication Response (code or idtoken/access token)

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the ID Token is accepted by the client and the attacker is logged into the victim's account.

Mitigation

A complete mitigation of the attack is not officially specifyed yet, but currently discussed. The proper usage of the state parameter hampers the attack, but does not prevent it. We recommend binding the state parameter to the session AND the corresponding IdP. Usage of client_secret_jwt or private_key_jwt can help to prevent leakage of client credentials. In addition, appropriate CSRF countermeasures should be implemented by the client.

TestStep.Name: Session Overwriting 2
TestStep.Description:
Session Overwriting 2

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

The Session Overwriting test consists of five steps and requires the participation of the Attacker OP and the Honest OP.
  • Step 1: starts authentication with Malicious OP
  • Step 2: pause before sending the Authentication Response (code or idtoken/access token) to the SP
  • Step 3: start authentication with Honest OP within the same HTTP session as Step 1 (i.e., use the same Cookies)
  • Step 4: abort Step 3 after the Honest OP has been contacted by the Browser from Step 3.
  • Step 5: continue with Step 2 (break the pause) and sends the Authentication Response (code or idtoken/access token). The ID Token's iss claim is set to the issuer value of the Honest OP, even though the ID Token is generated by the Malicious OP.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the ID Token is accepted by the client and the attacker is logged on the victim's account.

Mitigation

When verifying the received ID Token, the client must take care to use the correct key material, which has been established with Honest OP during registration.

Signature Manipulation

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token containing invalid signature and "none" algorithm.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the token is accepted by the client.

Mitigation

The signature MUST be validated, see Step 6 in Section 3.1.3.7 in OpenIDConnect-Core. The usage of the "nonce" algorithm is allowed in code flow. However, in implicit flow its usage is not allowed and the ID Token MUST NOT be accepted.

TestStep.Description:

TestStep.Name: Signature Manipulation 4
TestStep.Description:
Signature Manipulation

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token containing "none" algorithm in a mixed-case writing ("NoNe") and no signature. This may circumvent naive blacklisting of the "none" algorithm.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the token is accepted by the client.

Mitigation

The signature MUST be validated, see Step 6 in Section 3.1.3.7 in OpenIDConnect-Core. The usage of the "nonce" algorithm is allowed in code flow. However, in implicit flow its usage is not allowed and the ID Token MUST NOT be accepted.

TestStep.Name: CSRF 1
TestStep.Description:
CSRF Protection via the state parameter

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the state parameter on the client.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS returns invalid state parameter.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the Authentication Response is accepted despite the fact the the state parameter is missing or invalid and the next protocol steps are executed. Code flow: A token request containing the code is sent to the Attacker OP Implicit flow: The attacker is successfully logged on his account.

Mitigation

The state parameter MUST be validated, see Section 3.2.2.5. in OpenIDConnect-Core. 1) The state must be bound to the End-User Session (e.g. cookies) 2) The state must be bound to the sent Authentication Request.

TestStep.Name: CSRF 2
TestStep.Description:
CSRF Protection via the state parameter

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the state parameter on the client.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS returns state parameter issued in another browser session. Step 1: The browser is startet, the authentication with the MaliciousOP is initiated and the received parameter is cached. Then, the connection is dropped. Step 2: A new session in the browser is started and the authentication with the MaliciousOP is initiated. After receiving the Authentication Request, the Authentication Response is generated. But, now the received state parameter from step 1 is sent back to the client.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the Authentication Response is accepted despite the fact the the state parameter is missing or invalid and the next protocol steps are executed. Code flow: A token request containing the code is sent to the Attacker OP and afterwards the attacker is successfully logged on his account. Implicit flow: The attacker is successfully logged on his account.

Mitigation

The state parameter MUST be validated, see Section 3.2.2.5. in OpenIDConnect-Core. 1) The state must be bound to the End-User Session (e.g. cookies) 2) The state must be bound to the sent Authentication Request.

TestStep.Name: CSRF 3
TestStep.Description:
CSRF Protection via the state parameter

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the state parameter on the client. PrOfESSOS does not return the state parameter.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the Authentication Response is accepted despite the fact the the state parameter is missing or invalid and the next protocol steps are executed. Code flow: A token request containing the code is sent to the Attacker OP and afterwards the attacker is successfully logged on his account. Implicit flow: The attacker is successfully logged on his account.

Mitigation

The state parameter MUST be validated, see Section 3.2.2.5. in OpenIDConnect-Core. 1) The state must be bound to the End-User Session (e.g. cookies) 2) The state must be bound to the sent Authentication Request.

TestStep.Name: TRC 1
TestStep.Description:
Token Recipient Confusion Attack

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the aud (audience) parameter on the client by issuing maliciously crafted ID Tokens.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token that does not contain an aud claim.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the token is accepted by the client and the attacker is logged in his account.

Mitigation

The aud value MUST be validated, see Step 3 in Section 3.1.3.7 in OpenIDConnect-Core.

TestStep.Name: TRC 2
TestStep.Description:
Token Recipient Confusion Attack

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the "audience" parameter on the client by issuing maliciously crafted ID Tokens.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token that contains an invalid aud parameter.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the token is accepted by the client and the attacker is logged in his account.

Mitigation

The aud value MUST be validated, see Step 3 in Section 3.1.3.7 in OpenIDConnect-Core.

TestStep.Name: TRC 3
TestStep.Description:
Token Recipient Confusion Attack

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the "audience" parameter on the client by issuing maliciously crafted ID Tokens. The value of the aud claim is set to the audience value of the client registered at the Honest OP.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token containing an aud claim initialized with the Client ID of the client registered at the Honest OP.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the token is accepted by the client and the attacker is logged into his account.

Mitigation

The aud value MUST be validated, see Step 3 in Section 3.1.3.7 in OpenIDConnect-Core.

TestStep.Name: Token Substitution - AccessToken
TestStep.Description:
Token Substitution Attack

A client using an implicit grant may be subject to a Token Substitution Attack. This is a Cut and Paste attack, in which a malicious user copies a code or token from one session and places it inside a message that belongs to another session, e.g., of a legitimate user. PrOfESSOS tests the validation of Access Token on the client by issuing maliciously crafted ID Tokens. In this test, the Access Token is not bound to the ID Token, i.e., the value of the at_hash claim contained in the ID Token does not match.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the implicit flow or the code flow. Note that validation of the Access Token Hash is optional (MAY) when using the code flow and recommended (SHOULD) when using implicit grants.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token containing an at_hash claim initialized with a random value.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the Access Token is accepted by the client and submitted to the UserInfo endpoint.

Mitigation

As per RFC 6749, Section 10.16 Any specification that uses the authorization process as a form of delegated end-user authentication to the client (e.g., third-party sign-in service) MUST NOT use the implicit flow without additional security mechanisms that would enable the client to determine if the access token was issued for its use (e.g., audience- restricting the access token). OpenID Connect clients SHOULD validate Access Tokens and Authorization Codes retrieved with implicit grants using the binding to the ID Token provided in the at_hash and c_hash claims, according to OpenID Connect-Core 1.0, Sections 3.2.2.9 and 3.3.2.10.

TestStep.Name: Token Substitution - Authorization Code
TestStep.Description:
Token Substitution Attack

A client using an implicit grant may be subject to a Token Substitution Attack. This is a Cut and Paste attack, in which a malicious user copies a code or token from one session and places it inside a message that belongs to another session, e.g., of a legitimate user. PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the Authorization Code on the client by issuing a maliciously crafted ID Token. In this test, the Authorization Code is not bound to the ID Token, i.e., the value of the c_hash claim contained in the ID Token does not match the actual hash value of the code.

Prerequisites.

The target client supports the hybrid flow. Note that validation of the Authorization Code Hash is optional (MAY) when using the code flow or the implicit flow and recommended (SHOULD) when using the hybrid flow.

Execution.

PrOfESSOS issues an ID Token containing an at_hash claim initialized with a random value.

Result Evaluation.

The attack is successful if the Auhtorization Code is accepted by the client and submitted to the Token endpoint.

Mitigation

OpenID Connect clients SHOULD validate Access Tokens and Authorization Codes retrieved with implicit grants using the binding to the ID Token provided in the at_hash and c_hash claims, according to OpenID Connect-Core 1.0, Sections 3.2.2.9 and 3.3.2.10.
